Question: A man lives on the 15th floor of an apartment building.
Every morning, he takes the elevator down to the ground floor to go to work.
In the evening, when he returns from work, he takes the elevator to the 10th floor and then walks up the stairs for the remaining five floors to his apartment.
However, on rainy days, he takes the elevator all the way to the 15th floor.

Why does he do this? 

 Solution: 
<think>
Okay, so I'm trying to figure out why this man takes the elevator all the way to the 15th floor on rainy days.
Let me start by breaking down the problem step by step.
First, the man lives on the 15th floor.
Every morning, he takes the elevator down to the ground floor (which is the 1st floor) to go to work.
In the evening, when he returns, he takes the elevator up to the 10th floor and then walks up the remaining five floors to his apartment.
But on rainy days, he takes the elevator all the way to the 15th floor.
I need to understand why this difference occurs.
Let me think about why he doesn't take the elevator all the way in the evening on normal days.
If he lives on the 15th floor and works on the ground floor, during normal days, he goes down to work in the morning.
In the evening, when he returns, he takes the elevator up to the 10th floor and walks up five floors.
So, on normal days, he doesn't take the elevator all the way home.
But on rainy days, he does.
Maybe it's about the time it takes.
Perhaps on rainy days, the elevator is slower, so it takes longer to go up to the 15th floor.
But wait, the problem doesn't mention anything about the elevator's speed.
Maybe it's about the effort or the routine.
Alternatively, maybe it's about the weather affecting his commute.
If it's raining, perhaps he doesn't want to get wet by walking the five floors.
So, on rainy days, he takes the elevator all the way up to avoid getting wet.
But the problem says he takes the elevator to the 10th floor and walks up five floors on normal days.
So, perhaps on normal days, he doesn't mind walking a bit, but on rainy days, he prefers to stay dry.
That makes sense.
Wait, but the problem doesn't mention anything about the weather affecting his walking.
It's more about the elevator.
Maybe the building has an issue where the elevator doesn't go all the way up on rainy days.
Or perhaps he prefers not to get his clothes wet by taking the elevator on rainy days.
Hmm, that doesn't quite make sense.
Another angle: maybe the elevator is out of service or not functioning properly on rainy days, so he can't go all the way up.
But that seems unlikely because the problem says he takes the elevator all the way on rainy days, implying it's working.
Wait, perhaps it's about the time he saves.
If he takes the elevator all the way up on rainy days, maybe the elevator is faster, but that contradicts the normal days where he takes the elevator to the 10th floor.

Alternatively, maybe on rainy days, he's in a hurry, so he takes the elevator all the way to save time, whereas on normal days, he prefers to walk the last five floors to get some exercise or to avoid waiting for the elevator.
But the problem doesn't mention time or exercise, so maybe it's about the weather.
He doesn't want to get wet, so he takes the elevator all the way up.
That seems plausible.
So, putting it all together, on normal days, he takes the elevator up to the 10th floor and walks up five floors because it's not raining, and he doesn't mind walking.
But on rainy days, he takes the elevator all the way up to avoid getting wet.

</think>

The man takes the elevator all the way to the 15th floor on rainy days to avoid getting wet while walking up the stairs.
